Agency/Organization: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
Resource Name: AHRQ Social Determinants of Health Database
Data Description: The purpose of this project is to create easy to use, easily linkable SDOH-focused data to use in PCOR research, inform approaches to address emerging health issues, and ultimately contribute to improved health outcomes. These SDOH beta data files are curated from existing Federal datasets and other publicly available data sources. The purpose of the files is to make it easier to find a range of well documented, readily linkable SDOH variables across domains without having to access multiple source files, facilitating SDOH research and analysis.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Demographics, Population distribution, Age, Race/ethnicity, Social Vulnerability Index, Segregation, Living Conditions, Workforce / Employment, Poverty, Income, Education, Health Insurance Status, Health care system characteristics, Health status- mortality, Population density

Agency/Organization: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
Data Description:
The Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project (HCUP, pronounced "H-Cup") is a family of databases, software tools and related products developed through a Federal-State-Industry partnership and sponsored by AHRQ. HCUP databases are derived from administrative data and contain encounter-level, clinical and nonclinical information including all-listed diagnoses and procedures, discharge status, patient demographics, and charges for all patients, regardless of payer (e.g., Medicare, Medicaid, private insurance, uninsured), beginning in 1988. These databases enable research on a broad range of health policy issues, including cost and quality of health services, medical practice patterns, access to health care programs, and outcomes of treatments at the national, State, and local market levels.

The HCUP databases are based on the data collection efforts of data organizations in participating States that have partnered with AHRQ.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Adult and pediatric ICD-10-CM/PCS diagnosis, procedure, External cause of morbidity codes, and patient characteristics

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Data Description: Electronic health surveillance data integration platform. Patient encounter data received from ED, urgent and abulatory care centers, inpatient healthcare settings, and labs. Secure data system- must request access as data is not publicly available.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Chief Complaint, Diagnosis Discharge, EMR data from disaster medical assistance team (DMAT) operation sites

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Data Description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Wide-ranging Online Data for Epidemiologic Research (CDC WONDER) is a web-based resource that provides state and county level vital statistic data for births, deaths, and infant mortality.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Infant birth weight, Pregnancy characteristics, Mortality, and Cancer

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) Vital Records - National Vital Statistics System (NVSS)
Data Description: Public use Birth, Period Linked Birth, Infant Death, Birth Cohort Linked Birth, Mortality Multiple Cause, and Fetal Death data files are available for independent research and analyses.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Maternal Behavior and Health Characteristics, Infant Health Characteristics, Medical and Public Services Utilization

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Data Description: Brings together health and environmental data from national, state, and city sources. Includes an interactive online data explorer (can generate maps, tables charts) as well as several downloadable datasets on drought, solar radiation, and air pollution. Examples of health data include asthma, birth defects, cancer, COPD, developmental, heart disease, heat stress, reproductive and birth outcomes, hormone disorders, etc.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Asthma, Cancer, Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), Developmental Disabilities, Lifestyle factors, and Reproductive and Birth Outcomes

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: Web-based Injury Statistics Query and Reporting System (WISQARS)
Data Description: CDC's WISQARs is an interactive, online database that provides fatal and nonfatal injury, violent death, and cost of injury data. Researchers, the media, public health professionals, and the public can use WISQARS data to learn more about the public health and economic burden associated with unintentional and violence-related injury in the United States.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Injury Fire/Burn

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: U.S. Cancer Statistics Public Use Databases
Data Description:
De-identified cancer incidence data reported to CDC's National Program of Cancer Registries (NPCR) and the National Cancer Institutes (NCIs) Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program are available to researchers for free in public use databases that can be analyzed using software developed by NCIs SEER Program.

Cancer surveillance data from CDC and NCI are combined to become U.S. Cancer Statistics, the official source for federal cancer data. U.S. Cancer Statistics public use databases include cancer incidence and population data for all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico, providing information on more than 33 million cancer cases.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Cancer Incidence (e.g., lung cancer, brain tumours, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, multiple myeloma, and leukaemia) using ICD-1O codes, Month of Diagnosis

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Data Description: NHCS collects data on patient care in hospital-based settings to describe patterns of health care delivery and utilization in the United States. Settings include inpatient, emergency (EDs), and outpatient departments (OPDs). The survey will provide hospital utilization statistics for the Nation. In addition, NHCS will also be able to monitor national trends in substance use-related ED visits including opioid visits. Researchers can link these survey data to outside data sources such as the National Death Index (NDI) to obtain a more complete picture of patient care.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Demographics, Diagnoses (ICD-10 codes), Procedures, Laboratory tests, and Medications

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Data Description: Containing over 100 million death records, the National Death Index (NDI) can help you find out who in your study has died by linking your own research datasets to death certificate information for your study subjects.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: ICD-10 Codes

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: National Vital Statistics System Mortality Files on Drug overdose deaths (NVSS-M-DO)
Data Description:
The National Vital Statistics System collects and shares critical information on deaths from drug overdoses, such as what substances were used and where deaths are happening in America. Our systems receive and analyze data from death certificates, including cause-of-death information reported by medical examiners and coroners. Because drug overdose deaths often require lengthy investigations, data are updated as new information is received.

Information about which drugs were involved in a death comes from the literal text description of the cause of death, which is written on the death certificate by the medical certifier. The cause-of-death literal text is coded to ICD-10 codes for reporting or can be analyzed directly. Drug overdose deaths involving multiple drugs may be included in more than one category in our reporting
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: ICD-10 Underlying Cause of Death, Specific Substances Mentioned in Report, and Non-Specific Substances Mentioned in Report

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: Linked National Hospital Care Survey (NCHS) and National Death Index (NDI) Mortality Data
Data Description: Through its data linkage program, NCHS has been able to expand the analytic utility of the data collected from National Hospital Care Survey (NHCS) by augmenting it with mortality data from the National Death Index (NDI). Linkage of NHCS data with the NDI mortality data provides the opportunity to conduct a vast array of outcome studies designed to investigate the association of a wide variety of health factors with mortality.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Day/Month/Year of Birth; Day/Month/Year of Death; ICD-10 Underlying Cause of Death; Other Conditions/Comborbidities

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: Linked NHCS and CMS Medicare Master Beneficiary Summary File (MBSF) Data and Linked NHCS and CMS Medicare MBSF Claims/Encounters and Assessment Data
Data Description:
Through its data linkage program, NCHS has been able to expand the analytic utility of the data collected from the National Hospital Care Survey (NHCS) by augmenting it with administrative data from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Medicare program. Linkage of NHCS data with the CMS Medicare Data provides the opportunity to conduct a vast array of studies on health care utilization and expenditures among the elderly U.S. population and persons receiving Medicare disability benefits.

Medicare enrollment and claims/encounters data are available for patient records in the NHCS for which NCHS was able to match with Medicare administrative records. CMS provided NCHS with Medicare enrollment and health care claims/encounters data for all successfully matched patient records.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Patient Ambulatory Care and Inpatient Visits - Detailed Info About Hospital Characteristics, Patients' Characteristics, and Treatment, includes PII. CMS Data Includes Beneficiary Demographic Characteristics, Reason for Medicare Entitlement, and Program Enrollment Type - Allows for Analyses Combining Comorbidities and Utilization of Non-Inpatient Related Health Care Services.

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: NHCS and NDI linked with the National Vital Statistics System mortality files on drug overdose deaths (NVSS-M-DO) file
Data Description: The dataset includes the following: 1) Merged 2014 NHCS/NDI/NVSS-M-DO, and 2) Merged 2016 NHCS/NDI/NVSS-M-DO. Analysis of this data set will result in a report exploring characteristics of individuals who have opioid-related events, patterns of hospital use in months prior to death, and comparison of patients and services.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Patient Demographics, Care Setting, Expected Source of Payment, Diagnoses, Procedures, Beginning/Ending Service date, Length of Stay, Discharge Status, Death in Hospital, Hospital Demographics, Underlying Cause of Death, Multiple Causes of Death, Date of Birth/Death, Specific Substances, Drug Classes, Non-Specific Substances

Data Description: Patient zip-code level data available in the following datasets: Skilled Nursing Facility (encounter), Outpatient (encounter), Inpatient (encounter), home health agency (encounter), and DME (encounter) - datasets also include info such as diagnostic codes, discharge status, and other patient demographics. Files must be requested d/t idenfiable information (some publicly available datasets but don't have the level of detail that would be needed - typically reported as annual frequencies, not at county level)
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Diagnostic Codes, Discharge Status, Patient Demographics

Data Description: Open-source computer program that calculates the number and economic value of air pollution-related (PM2.5 and O3) deaths and illnesses. Incorporates a database that includes many concentration-response relationships, population files, and health and economic data to quality impacts. Can also add in EPA Air Quality System data to be used along with BenMAP application.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Modeling includes baseline rates. The Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation-developed baseline death rates (year 2013) for 4 mortality endpoints (COPD, cerebrovascular disease, ischemic heart disease, and lung cancer) stratified by age and sex.

Resource Name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) Mental Health Client-Level Data (MH-CLD)
Data Description: MH-CLH and the Mental Health Treatment Episode Data Set (MH-TEDS) provide information on mental health diagnoses and the mental health treatment services, outcomes, and demographic and substance use characteristics of individuals in mental health treatment facilities that report to individual state administrative data systems.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: ICD-10 codes (e.g., asthma, cardiovascular, pregnancy and birth outcomes etc.)

Data Description: NPIRS is a database of financial, environmental, engineering, administrative and clinical healthcare information gathered from direct IHS, Tribal and Urban healthcare sites & regional administrative offices throughout the Indian Health systems. Data from over 500 healthcare sites and 12 regional offices in 35 states.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Injury, Clinical services

Data Description: 439 clinical and administrative datasets available for the state of CA (includes patient discharge data, ED encounters, inpatient characteristics, asthma rates, infectious disease etc.).
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Varies by Dataset (e.g., ICD-10 codes, number of ED vists for asthma, confirmed coccidioidomycosis (valley fever) cases, birthweight etc.)

Data Description: The birth files include all state registered births, and births to California residents that occurred out-of-state. These files contain detailed demographic information related to the child, mother, and father, as well as medical data related to the birth.  CPHS and VSAC approvals are required to obtain the confidential data fields. The death files are available with in-state California deaths only, a combination of in-state deaths and deaths of California residents that occurred in other states or jurisdictions, or out-of-state deaths only.  CPHS and the VSAC approvals may be required to obtain the death files. In addition, Public Use and Anti-Fraud data files are available.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Demographic and medical data related to birth, place of birth; Death records include birth/death info, demographics, place and cause of death, includes variable indicating whether death was disaster-related

Data Description: The California Cancer Registry (CCR) is California's statewide population-based cancer surveillance system. The CCR collects information about all cancers diagnosed in California (except basal and squamous cell carcinoma of the skin and carcinoma in situ of the cervix).
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: ICD-1O codes (e.g., lung cancer, brain tumours, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, multiple myeloma, leukaemia etc.)

Data Description: The Oregon State Cancer Registry (OSCaR) was established in August 1995, after the Oregon Legislature unanimously passed legislation making cancer a reportable disease. OSCaR is a statewide, population-based registry that collects and analyzes information about cancer cases occurring in Oregon. The mission of the Oregon State Cancer Registry is to collect complete, quality cancer data that supports cancer research and public health practices designed to improve efforts in the screening, treatment and survivorship of all people in Oregon affected by cancer.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: ICD-10-CM ( (e.g., lung cancer, brain tumours, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, multiple myeloma, leukaemia etc.)

Data Description: Data and reports on a variety of health topics including cancer, infectious diseases, environmental health, health behavior, vital statistics, hospital data, injury and poisoning, material and child health.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Demographics, Birth and death records, Cancer diagnosis, Injury data

Data Description: Washington State Department of Health program focused on making public health data more accessible. Data are available for download and exploration using five tools (dashboards, data portal, information by location, community reports). Topic areas: health outcomes and surveillance, demographics and community characteristics, climate change and the environment.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: WA DPH data including BRFS, Cancer incidence, Birth outcomes etc.

Resource Name: Washington State All Payer Claims Database (WA-APCD)
Data Description: The Washington State All Payer Claims Database (WA-APCD) is a tool used to collect health care claims data for reporting, analytics, and to help the public make their health care decisions. It supports health care and payment reform while addressing the need for cost, quality, and utilization transparency. Using the WA-APCD, Washington State can help to advance medicine and public health
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: ICD-10 and CPT codes (e.g., asthma, cardiovascular,pregnancy and birth outcomes etc.)

Scale Level: N/A ; Data is Broken Up into Cohorts
Data Description: The Kaiser Permanente (KP) Research Bank is the second largest biobank in the US. It provides an exceptional opportunity to enable research studies related to the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of disease. KP makes this core resource including de-identified medical record information, a health survey and biospecimens available to scientists who apply to use the information for genetic, epidemiological, and other scientific research.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: EMR data, Pregnancy cohort, Cancer cohort

Data Description: IQVIA proprietary datasets include: Electronic Medical Records (EMR), Longitudinal Prescription (LRx), Claims data, Hospital Data, Genomic Data, Oncology Data, and Biomedical Global data.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: EMR data, Prescriptions, and Claims

Data Description: A proprietary softward used to conduct healthcare research. Additionally, IBM Marketscan allows the user to interact with cloud-based tools for visual patient analytics and allows for access to the MarketScan Research Data.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: N/A

Data Description: Integrating and linking deep patient data from multiple real-world sources to clarify and allow for clinical decision making.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: N/A

Resource Name: Environmental influences on Child Health Outcomes (ECHO) Program
Data Description: In 2016 NIH launched a seven-year initiative called the Environmental influences on Child Health Outcomes (ECHO) Program. ECHO capitalizes on existing participant populations and supports approaches that can evolve with the science and take advantage of the growing number of clinical research networks and technological advances.The ECHO Program has two major components, the ECHO cohorts for observational research, and the ECHO IDeA States Pediatric Clinical Trials Network (ISPCTN) for intervention research. The cohorts share standardized core data elements managed by a central coordinating center and an associated data analysis center. Although each cohort is unique, the collection of data in a similar way ensures that all information can be combined and used by researchers. The core elements addressed across all studies are: demographics, typical early health and development,  genetic influences on early childhood health and development, environmental factors, patient/Person (parent and child) Reported Outcomes (PROs). The ECHO cohorts capitalize on existing participant populations that include children from diverse background across the United States, and support approaches that can evolve with the science and take advantage of technological advances. As of May 2022, the cohorts have data from over 100,000 participants, which includes over 61,000 children.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Varies by cohort

Resource Name: Smoke Sense Study: A Citizen Science Project Using a Mobile App
Data Description: Smoke Sense is a crowdsourcing, citizen science research project developed by EPA researchers focused on increasing public awareness and engagement related to wildfire smoke health risks. Specifically, EPA wants to understand the extent that exposure to wildland fire smoke affects health and productivity, discover what steps people are willing to take to reduce their exposure, and develop health risk communication strategies that improve public health when there is wildfire smoke.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: N/A

Resource Name: Geospatial Data Science Applications and Visualizations
Data Description: The Geospatial Data Science (GDS) group in NRELs Strategic Energy Analysis Center leads modeling and visualization research at the intersection of renewable energy deployment, geospatial technologies, big data science, and application development.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Wind, Solar, Biofuels

Data Description: This map provides information about land use in the unincorporate area of Sonoma County including zoning, zoning overly, land use, land development and density. The map is updated based on Sonoma Counties General Plan.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Land Use

Data Description: Web Soil Survey (WSS) provides soil data and information produced by the National Cooperative Soil Survey. It is operated by the USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) and provides access to the largest natural resource information system in the world. NRCS has soil maps and data available online for more than 95 percent of the nations counties and anticipates having 100 percent in the near future. The site is updated and maintained online as the single authoritative source of soil survey information.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Soil quality

Data Description: Used as a proxy for health outcomes/exposures. Publicy available data that can be used to analyze location-specific variation in search query behavior.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Search term popularity; Behavior; Future purchasing (of protective equipment)

Data Description: Used as a proxy for health outcomes/exposures. Geolocated tweets can be downloaded using Twitter's API.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Sentiment; Behavior

Data Description: Used as proxy for health outcome. These data measure the aggregate activity of anonymized device signals, or pings, at the census block group level. Signals are collected from smartphones, not all cell phones.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Mobility, Migration

Data Description: Lumosity hosts a variety of cognitive training "games" from which data is available upon request. Researchers used data to assess cogntive impacts of wildfire.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Cognitive performance, Attention score

Agency/Organization: California Department of Forestry and Fire Proection (CAL FIRE)
Data Description:
Reports of wildfire incidents, acreage burned, and location of wildfires. 
 (vegetation removal)
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Wildfire damage, incident counts, locations etc.

Data Description: Landscape scale geo-spatial products to support cross-boundary planning, management, and operations . LANDFIRE is a real-time tool that sicerns areas with the highest wildfire risk.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Topographic maps for fuel, vegetation, fire regime, and seasonal

Data Description: MTBS is an interagency program focused on mapping the burn severity and extent of large wildfires.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Fire name, Acreage, Ignition date, Fire type, Fire ID

Resource Name: Emergency Assessment of Post-Fire Debris-Flow Hazards
Data Description: Wildfires can significantly alter the hydrologic response of a watershed to the extent that even modest rainstorms can produce dangerous flash floods and debris flows. The USGS conducts post-fire debris-flow hazard assessments for select fires in the Western U.S. The USGS uses geospatial data related to basin morphometry, burn severity, soil properties, and rainfall characteristics to estimate the probability and volume of debris flows that may occur in response to a design storm.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Date of origin, Location, Acreage, Segmented probability

Resource Name: Gridded Surface Smoke and Non-Smoke PM2.5
Data Description: This dataset contains spatially interpolated daily PM2.5 concentrations observed by monitors in the Environmental Protection Agency's Air Quality System and non-smoke seasonal background PM2.5 estimates for 2006-2015.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Looks at wildfire smoke epidemiology, Health-impact assessments, Economics, etc.

Agency/Organization: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) ; National Weather Service (NWS)
Data Description: The goal of the NWS is to provide weather, water and climate data, forecasts, warnings, and impact-based decision support services for the protection of life and property and enhancement of the national economy.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: General weather, wind, temp, precipitation etc.

Agency/Organization: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) ; National Weather Service (NWS)
Data Description: Site specific NWS spot forecast requests for wildfires or prescribed burns which provides a 48 hour forecast.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Spot weather forecasts (forecasts issued to fit time, topography and weather of specific incidents)

Agency/Organization: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) ; National Weather Service (NWS)
Resource Name: NOAA Operational Model Archive and Distribution System (NOMADS)
Data Description: NCEP delivers national and global weather, water, climate and space weather guidance, forecasts, warnings and analyses to its Partners and External User Communities. These products and services are based on a service-science legacy and respond to user needs to protect life and property, enhance the nation's economy and support the nation's growing need for environmental information.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Weather forecasting data

Data Description: The MADIS Application Program Interface (API) is a library of subroutines, callable from Fortran, which provides access to all of the observation and quality control (QC) information in the MADIS database (referred to as the "FSL database" in the API documentation), and/or other supported meteorological databases (i.e., the NWS AWIPS netCDF database). In general, the API is very easy use to wit
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: N/A

Data Description: The FIREX FireLab 2016 study is a coordinated effort based at the USDA Fire Sciences Lab in Missoula, Montana. Experiments focus on refining our understanding of emissions and short timescale processing using the instruments and methods that have been developed during the first years of FIREX (Fire Influence on Regional and Global Environments Experiment, which evolved into FIREX-AQ). The focus is on measuring fuels or combustion conditions that are characteristic of the western U.S. that may be under-sampled by the fire research community and in the follow-up study of fuels from fires observed during the 2019 intensive field study.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Air pollutants/quality

Data Description: The Rapid Refresh is the continental-scale NOAA hourly-updated assimilation/modeling system operational at NCEP. RAP covers North America and is comprised primarily of a numerical forecast model and an analysis/assimilation system to initialize that model. RAP is complemented by the higher-resolution 3km High-Resolution Rapid Refresh (HRRR) model, which is also updated hourly and covering a smaller geographic domain.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Air quality prediction

Agency/Organization: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) ; National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)
Resource Name: Satellite in HMS: G16/17, VIIRS NOAA20/JPSS, MODIS/Terra
Data Description: To detect active fire pixels and the extent of smoke plumes. Data collected is based on Mission.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Smoke plumes, Cloud cover, Haze, Sea surface heights, GOES satellite measurements

Resource Name: VIIRS I-band Active Fire Visual Display
Data Description: RealEarth™ is a data discovery and visualization platform developed at SSEC/CIMSS at the University of Wisconsin-Madison to support outreach and collaboration efforts of scientists. The goal is to allow quick and continuous visualization of Earth observation imagery and data in a common and familiar map-based interface.  Because the system is built with geographic information system or GIS awareness AND the needs of meteorologic and atmospheric scientists in mind, a wide variety of land, oceanic, and atmospheric remote sensing imagery and related data are available to be layered, compared, and animated in time-series loops.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Fire radiative power

Resource Name: Global Biomass Burning Emissions Product eXtended (GBBEPx)
Data Description: The Blended Global Biomass Burning Emissions Product version 3 (GBBEPx V3) system produces global biomass burning emissions. The product contains daily global biomass burning emissions (PM2.5, BC, CO, CO2, OC, and SO2) blended fire observations from MODIS Quick Fire Emission Dataset (QFED), VIIRS (NPP and JPSS-1) fire emissions, and Global Biomass Burning Emission Product from Geostationary satellites (GBBEP-Geo), which are in a grid cell of 0.25 _ 0.3125 degree and 0.1 x 0.1 degree.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Air Quality (PM2.5, emissions, GBBEP, biomass burning)

Data Description: EPA plans to ingest the near real time surface PM2.5 estimates into its AirNow system. Data has been collected since 2021.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Air Quality (PM2.5, emissions, cloud cover), Satellite Imagery, Wildfires

Data Description: The data is provided to the NWS for model verification. The data is also provided to the public in near real time via AerosolWatch website.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Air/Wind patterns and currents

Data Description: This website prototypes the usage of VOLCAT Thermal Anomaly detection and characterization applied to wildfires over CONUS. This project is a collaboration between the VOLCAT team and NOAA Wildfire teams and allows for the rapid detection of wildfire events.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Thermal anomaly detection

Data Description: NOAA/NESDIS Satellite Analysis Branch's Hazard Mapping System (HMS) was first implemented in 2003 in response to high demand for active fire and smoke information over North America. The system combines near real-time polar and geostationary satellite observations into a common framework in which expert image analysts perform quality control of automated fire products and digitization of smoke plumes.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Wildfires and smoke presence

Agency/Organization: Environmntal Protection Agency (EPA) ; United States Forest Service (USFS)
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Air Quality, Smoke plumes, Wildfire presence, Terrain maps

Agency/Organization: United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) ; United States Forest Service (USFS)
Data Description: This joint USDA/Forest Service GIS platform allows users to identify Wildland Urban Interface (WUI) areas. WUI areas are areas where houses/structures meet or interface with undeveloped vegetation. The primary concern are fires burning in the WUI might emit more toxic mixtures than wildland fires.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Wildland Urban Interface (WUI) locations, topography

Data Description: The Fire Information for Resource Management System (FIRMS) distributes Near Real-Time (NRT) active fire data from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) aboard the Aqua and Terra satellites, and the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) aboard S-NPP and NOAA 20 (formally known as JPSS-1). Globally these data are available within 3 hours of satellite observation, but for the US and Canada active fire detections are available in real-time.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Fire location and intensity (fire radiative power)

Data Description: This open source code app from NASA's EOSDIS provides the capability to interactively browse over 1000 global, full-resolution satellite imagery layers and then download the underlying data. Many of the imagery layers are updated daily and are available within three hours of observation - essentially showing the entire Earth as it looks "right now". This supports time-critical application areas such as wildfire management, air quality measurements, and flood monitoring.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Smoke expension, Smoke optical properties, Atmospheric indicators

Data Description: An interface for latest near real-time and disaster specific data products in Geographic Information Systems (GIS) format. The Disasters Mapping Portal supports NASAs Earth Applied Sciences Disasters program area in its mission to use Earth-observing data and applied research to improve the prediction of, preparation for, response to and recovery from hazards and disasters around the world.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Fire location, Air quality, plume height, Aerosol optical Depth, Damage proxy maps, Debris flows, Hurricanes, Volcano eruptions, Disasters (general)
Timeframe (Can Vary Based on DataSet): Wildfires from 2020 - Present. Other Data dependent on GIS layer

Data Description: NASA's Land, Atmosphere Near real-time Capability for EOS (LANCE) provides near real-time data and imagery within 3 hours from satellite observation, including MODIS and VIIRS/Suomi NPP Active Fires near real-time data products.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Data sets in MODIS near real-time Thermal Anomalies/Fire products include fire-mask, Algorithm quality assurance, Radiative power and numerous layers describing fire pixel attributes.                                                                        Information in VIIRS/NPP near real-time Active Fires products include fire mask, Fire pixel latitude and longitude, Fire pixels I4 and I5 brightness temperatures (BT), Background I4 and I5 BTs, Background I4 and I5 BT mean absolute deviation, Background I4-I5 BT difference mean absolute deviation, Fire pixels M13 radiance, Background M13 radiance, Mean background I4-I5 BT difference, Fire radiative power (FRP), Number of adjacent cloud pixels, Number of adjacent water pixels, Background window size, Detection confidence.

Data Description: This collaborative portal aims to bring together data from various organizations to allow for informed decision making in the different phases of a wildfire which includes pre- active and post.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: N/A ; Site is currently in development.

Agency/Organization: California Department of Forestry and Fire Proection (CAL FIRE)
Data Description: The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection's Fire and Resource Assessment Program (FRAP) assesses the amount and extent of California's forests and rangelands, analyzes their conditions and identifies alternative management and policy guidelines. Included in FRAP are a variety of measurements included in GIS portals.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Vegetation, Watershed, Fire characteristics, Erosion, WUI, County Boundaries, Fire Threat, Fire Severity, Land Ownership

Data Description: PurpleAir's industry-leading sensors measure particle pollution (PM2.5) and are priced at a fraction of what you pay for a commercial sensor. This data is available to view for free, but data availability is dependant on presence of PurpleAir sensors.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Air Quality (Indoor and Outdoor) , PM 2.5

Resource Name: CARB Air Quality and Meteorological Information System
Data Description: CARB is charged with protecting the public from the harmful effects of air pollution and developing programs and actions to fight climate change. CARBs AQMIS system provides users with a variety of air quality measurements that can be overlayed with google maps.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Ozone, Air Quality, Meteorological, Greenhouse Gases

Data Description: Sonoma County has put together a GIS map that allows users to identify evacuation zones, where to go in response to an evacuation notice, and when a notice is given.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Evacuation Zones

Data Description: The U.S. Drought Monitor (USDM) is updated each Thursday to show the location and intensity of drought across the country. This data is available for every state and county. The measurements are tracked using a 5 items scale raning from D0 , abnormally dry, to D4, Exceptional Drought.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Drought conditions, Precepitation levels

Data Description:
InciWeb is an interagency all-risk incident information management system. The system was developed with two primary missions:
-Provide the public a single source of incident related information
-Provide a standardized reporting tool for the Public Affairs community
A number of supporting systems automate the delivery of incident information to remote sources. This ensures that the information regarding active incidents is consistent, and the delivery is timely.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Fire location, Cause, Date of origin, Coordinates, Size, Fuels, # of personnel, Closures (includes post-fire information as well)

Data Description: Open source air quality data from a range of reference monitors and low cost sensors. Includes data on the following pollutant types: PM10, PM2.5, Sulfur dioxide (SO2), Carbon monoxide (CO), Nitrogen dioxide (NO2), Ozone (O3), or Black carbon (BC).
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Air Quality

Data Description: In order to better meet the Agency’s responsibilities related to the protection of public health and the environment, EPA has developed a new environmental justice (EJ) mapping and screening tool called EJScreen. It is based on nationally consistent data and an approach that combines environmental and demographic indicators in maps and reports.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Demographic (gender, race, language, education, employment), Industrial & environmental variables (hazardous waste, wastewater quality, ozone)
Timeframe (Can Vary Based on DataSet): Every Decade ; Dependant on Census Reports
Frequency of Updates: Annual; Reflects Most Recent Census Reports

Resource Name:
Consumer Confidence Reports
(Office of Ground Water and Drinking Water)
Data Description: The Consumer Confidence Reports (CCRs), or annual water quality reports, are a critical piece of the “right-to-know” rules. The purpose of CCRs is to provide customers with information on drinking water quality and allow them to make health-based decisions on drinking water consumption.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Water system websites & contact info, Client/population served, Drinking water sources and regulated contaminants, Potential health effects of any contaminant detected in violation with EPA, Educational info on nitrate, arsenic, or lead
Frequency of Updates: CCR Reports sent annually by July 1st

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: National Environmental Public Health Tracking Network
Data Description: The National Environmental Public Health Tracking Network (Tracking Network) brings together health data and environmental data from national, state, and city sources and provides supporting information to make the data easier to understand. The Tracking Network has data and information on environments and hazards, health effects, and population health.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Data sources include, but not limited to, socioeconomic indices, public health, and climate change, Population (social vulnerability index, CDC's 500 Cities Project (2016-2019, replaced by PLACES Project in Dec 2020)), Environmental & hazards (climate change, community characteristics, toxic substance, children's environmental health), Health (asthma, cancer, pulmonary & heart diseases)

Resource Name: Health Center Program Uniform Data System (UDS)
Data Description: Health Center Program awardees and look-alikes are required to report on a core set of measures each calendar year as defined in the UDS, a standardized reporting system. HRSA uses UDS data to assess the impact and performance of the Health Center Program, and to promote data-driven quality improvement. Explore aggregated UDS data on health center patient characteristics, services provided, clinical processes and health outcomes, patients' use of services, staffing, costs, and revenues.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Patient characteristics (poverty level, insurance status, race & ethnicity, veterans, Medicare), Clinical (prenatal care, diabetes, cancer), Health outcomes & disparities, Medical costs
Frequency of Updates: Annually depending on report type requested

Agency/Organization: Sonoma County Department of Health Services
Data Description: The Profile of Leading Health Indicators contains high-level summary data, derived from local and state sources, highlighting major health conditions or events that compromise the health and healthy development of children and contribute most prominently to illness and injury, disability and death for Sonoma County adults and children. The Profile begins with population-wide data on leading causes of death by total population and by age group. Data on the burden of premature death are presented, as is information on types of disability by age.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Mortality and Morbidity, Disability by Age, Health Indicators (General), Leading Causes of Death by Age, Hospitilizations, Injuries by Age

Data Description: The California Department of Public Health (CDPH) works to protect the public's health in the Golden State and helps shape positive health outcomes for individuals, families and communities. The Department's programs and services, implemented in collaboration with local health departments and state, federal and private partners, touch the lives of every Californian and visitor to the state 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Healthcare, Demographics, Facilities and Services, Diseases and Conditions, Workforce, Environment

Agency/Organization: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)
Resource Name: 2020 Uniform Reporting System (URS) Table For California
Data Description: State mental health agencies (SMHAs) use the Uniform Reporting Systems (URS) to compile and report annual data as part of SAMHSA’s Community Mental Health Services Block Grant. URS is part of an effort to use data in decision support and planning in public mental health systems and in supporting program accountability.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Survey measures, Positive outcomes inadequately addressed, Age groups, Hospitalization by residence types, Mental health measures

Agency/Organization: Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) ; US Fire Administration
Data Description: State Fire Profiles provide users with a snapshot of state fire losses reported through the National Fire Incident Reporting System (NFIRS) in 2020. Casualties are included in this data.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Incident Types, Casualties/Fatalities, Fire Department Composition and Specialization

Data Description: The American Community Survey (ACS) helps local officials, community leaders, and businesses understand the changes taking place in their communities. It is the premier source for detailed population and housing information about our nation.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Demographics, Socio-economic Factors, Population Distributions, Population Vulnerabilities, Emergency Response and Evacuation Planning

Data Description: A USGS web application that enables the public to create custom topographic maps on demand. The official name of the application is topoBuilder or OnDemand Topos.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Structures (select medical and emergency response incl hospitals, Ambulance services, and fire stations/EMS, education, Law enforcement), Geographic Names, Canopy cover, Shrublands (NLCD data), Slope map for elevation

Agency/Organization: Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) - Administration for Children and Families (ACF)
Data Description: Point locations of Head Start funded programs. Head Start provides care and learning experiences for young children.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: General disaster data including hurricanes, eruptions, wildfires etc.

Data Description: Examines how at-risk every single neighborhood is to the impact of a disaster. The Community Resilience Estimates use single year microdata.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Social Vulnerability and equity gaps

Data Description: The Global Wildfire Information System (GWIS) is a joint initiative of the GEO and the Copernicus Work Programs. In the new GEO GWIS work program for the years 2020-2022 , the Global Wildfire Information System (GWIS) aims at bringing together existing information sources at regional and national level in order to provide a comprehensive view and evaluation of fire regimes and fire effects at global level and to provide tools to support operational wildfire management from national to global scales.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Historical data, Forecast, Damage assessment

Data Description: The Forecasting division conducts research on a variety of issues related to the state budget, public policy, and demographics. The Population unit develops official state and local population estimates and projections for use in the allocation of certain state revenues, growth management, and other planning functions. As the official partner of the U. S. Census Bureau for Washington state, the Population unit helps disseminate information about the characteristics of Washington’s population, housing, and economy and provide guidance to a variety of stakeholders in accessing and using demographic information.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Household income, Demographics, Demographics Forecasting, Housing, Population density,

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
Data Description: The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) is a program of studies designed to assess the health and nutritional status of adults and children in the United States. The survey is unique in that it combines interviews and physical examinations. NHANES is a major program of the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS). NCHS is part of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and has the responsibility for producing vital and health statistics for the Nation.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Demographics, Dietary, Laboratory Samples, Examination Data etc.

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Data Description: The Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) is the nations premier system of health-related telephone surveys that collect state data about U.S. residents regarding their health-related risk behaviors, chronic health conditions, and use of preventive services. Established in 1984 with 15 states, BRFSS now collects data in all 50 states as well as the District of Columbia and three U.S. territories. BRFSS completes more than 400,000 adult interviews each year, making it the largest continuously conducted health survey system in the world.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Demographics, Health Status, Tobacco/Alcohol Use, Chronic Health Conditions etc.

Agency/Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Resource Name: The Community Assessment for Public Health Emergency Response (CASPER)
Data Description: CASPER is a type of Rapid Needs Assessment (RNA) that provides household-level information to public health leaders and emergency managers. The information generated can be used to initiate public health action, identify information gaps; facilitate disaster planning, response, and recovery activities; allocate resources, and assess new or changing needs in the community. It is a cross-sectional epidemiologic design; it is not surveillance.
Variable Indicator Examples (But not lim: Public Health Perceptions, Estimating Needs of Community, Assist in Planning
